content.webTitle: Ravel: The Piano Concertos; Miroirs | CD review

fields.headline: Ravel: The Piano Concertos; Miroirs - review
fields.bodyText: As well as making a recording of the Concerto for the Left Hand early in his conducting career with Philippe Entremont for CBS, Pierre Boulez recorded the two Ravel concertos as a pairing in the 1990s, also for Deutsche Grammophon and with the Cleveland Orchestra, but with Krystian Zimerman as the exceptional soloist. Recorded live in Cleveland in February, Boulez and Pierre-Laurent Aimard make a combination that's almost equally formidable, though, especially in the left-handed work, where Boulez conjures up all the serpentine hues of the orchestral writing magnificently and Aimard gives a savage edge to the solo part. They are perhaps not so convincing in the G major concerto – Aimard's playing does not have quite the range of colour and gradations of touch that Zimerman, and before him Michelangeli (on EMI), bring to the piano writing, nor the infectious energy of Argerich's performance with Abbado (DG again). It's a distinguished disc, however – easily the most convincing of the three Boulez releases of this autumn – and Aimard completes it with the set of Miroirs, beautifully tooled and moulded, if just lacking a little in warmth.
